articles.headline: A Dying Banker’s Last Instructions
articles.snippet: Gordon Murray, a Wall Street veteran, has brain cancer and a desire to show people a better way to invest.
articles.abstract: Gordon Murray, a Wall Street veteran, has brain cancer and a desire to show people a better way to invest.
articles.lead_paragraph: BURLINGAME, Calif.

articles.headline: An American in Peru, Out of Jail but in Limbo
articles.snippet: Now released from prison, Lori Berenson shows a sense of regret, but a country may not be ready to forgive.
articles.abstract: Now released from prison, Lori Berenson shows a sense of regret, but a country may not be ready to forgive.
articles.lead_paragraph: LIMA, Peru

articles.headline: To Help Donors Choose, Web Site Alters How It Sizes Up Charities
articles.snippet: Charity Navigator, a Web site and organization, is overhauling itself and how it evaluates charitable organizations.
articles.abstract: Charity Navigator, a Web site and organization, is overhauling itself and how it evaluates charitable organizations.
articles.lead_paragraph: Charity Navigator, perhaps the largest online source for evaluating nonprofit groups, recently embarked on an overhaul to offer a wider, more nuanced array of information to donors who are deciding which organizations they might help.

articles.headline: Drug Maker Cited on Quality Issues
articles.snippet: A new F.D.A. inspection shows that a division of Johnson & Johnson has not corrected its manufacturing problems.
articles.abstract: A new F.D.A. inspection shows that a division of Johnson & Johnson has not corrected its manufacturing problems.
articles.lead_paragraph: Months after McNeil Consumer Healthcare, a unit of Johnson & Johnson, recalled millions of bottles of Tylenol and other over-the-counter drugs, the division is still plagued with manufacturing flaws, according to the Food and Drug Administration.

articles.headline: The Give and Take of Liar Loans
articles.snippet: Countrywide Financial’s stance on stated-income loans  better known as liar loans  depends on whether it’s being asked to buy those losers back or asking someone else to.
articles.abstract: Countrywide Financial’s stance on stated-income loans  better known as liar loans  depends on whether it’s being asked to buy those losers back or asking someone else to.
articles.lead_paragraph: Did you hear the one about Countrywide Financial demanding that mortgage originators buy back many of the so-called stated-income loans that it had purchased from them during the late great housing bubble?

articles.headline: G.M. Finds a More Receptive Public
articles.snippet: Evidence is emerging on car lots that consumers are starting to feel more positive about General Motors since it shed government control.
articles.abstract: Evidence is emerging on car lots that consumers are starting to feel more positive about General Motors since it shed government control.
articles.lead_paragraph: McHENRY, Ill.  One of the year’s biggest weekends for car dealers is also doubling as a coming-out party for General Motors, just a week after the company shed the government’s majority ownership. Evidence is emerging on car lots that consumers are starting to feel more positive about G.M. and less angry about the billions of dollars in federal aid it received.

articles.headline: A Bully Finds a Pulpit on the Web
articles.snippet: Vitaly Borker welcomes customer complaints, saying they vault his business higher in Internet search results.
articles.abstract: Vitaly Borker welcomes customer complaints, saying they vault his business higher in Internet search results.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHOPPING online in late July, Clarabelle Rodriguez typed the name of her favorite eyeglass brand into Google’s search bar.

articles.headline: Iraq’s Troubles Drive Out Refugees Who Came Back
articles.snippet: Iraqis who fled the height of the war and then returned are leaving in a second exodus, fueled by violence and unemployment, that shows how far Iraq remains from stability and security.
articles.abstract: Iraqis who fled the height of the war and then returned are leaving in a second exodus, fueled by violence and unemployment, that shows how far Iraq remains from stability and security.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  A second exodus has begun here, of Iraqis who returned after fleeing the carnage of the height of the war, but now find that violence and the nation’s severe lack of jobs are pulling them away from home once again.

articles.headline: F.B.I. Says Oregon Suspect Planned ‘Grand’ Attack
articles.snippet: F.B.I. officials said that a Somali-born suspect thought he was detonating a car bomb in a Christmas tree lighting ceremony in Portland, when in fact he had been set up in a sting.
articles.abstract: F.B.I. officials said that a Somali-born suspect thought he was detonating a car bomb in a Christmas tree lighting ceremony in Portland, when in fact he had been set up in a sting.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — A Somali-born teenager who thought he was detonating a car bomb at a packed Christmas tree-lighting ceremony downtown here was arrested by the authorities on Friday night after federal agents said that they had spent nearly six months setting up a sting operation.
articles.byline: By Colin Miner, Liz Robbins and Erik Eckholm

articles.headline: Don’t Just Tell Us. Show Us That You Can Foreclose.
articles.snippet: A unit of the Justice Department is increasing its scrutiny of banks that are seeking to foreclose, and asking them to prove they own the properties.
articles.abstract: A unit of the Justice Department is increasing its scrutiny of banks that are seeking to foreclose, and asking them to prove they own the properties.
articles.lead_paragraph: AFTER examining their foreclosure practices for flaws in mortgage documentation and other procedures, many of the nation’s largest banks have resumed  or will soon resume  trying to evict defaulted borrowers.

articles.headline: New Chairman Seeks More Power for Watchdogs
articles.snippet: Representative Darrell Issa, the Republican who will lead the House’s chief investigative committee, plans to expand scrutiny of the Obama administration.
articles.abstract: Representative Darrell Issa, the Republican who will lead the House’s chief investigative committee, plans to expand scrutiny of the Obama administration.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Republican who will lead the chief investigative committee in the House is planning to vastly expand scrutiny of the Obama administration by seeking new subpoena powers for dozens of federal agency watchdogs in hopes of using their investigations and his own in an aggressive push to cut spending and shrink the government.

articles.headline: Ex-Justice Criticizes Death Penalty
articles.snippet: Justice John Paul Stevens said he found the death penalty unconstitutional because of racism, politics and hysteria.
articles.abstract: Justice John Paul Stevens said he found the death penalty unconstitutional because of racism, politics and hysteria.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  In 1976, just six months after he joined the Supreme Court, Justice John Paul Stevens voted to reinstate capital punishment after a four-year moratorium. With the right procedures, he wrote, it is possible to ensure “evenhanded, rational and consistent imposition of death sentences under law.”

articles.headline: For ‘Lost Boy,’ Vote in Sudan Is Homecoming
articles.snippet: Southern Sudanese will soon hold a referendum to decide if they will split from the north. On the occasion of the vote, Joseph Gatyoung Khan came home.
articles.abstract: Southern Sudanese will soon hold a referendum to decide if they will split from the north. On the occasion of the vote, Joseph Gatyoung Khan came home.
articles.lead_paragraph: NYAL, Sudan  Joseph Gatyoung Khan made a vow, uttered in the back seat of a Land Cruiser on a very bumpy road, as he headed home for the first time in 22 years: I will not cry.

articles.headline: China Seeks Talks to Ease Korean Tension
articles.snippet: After the United States and South Korea began naval exercises as a warning to North Korea, China called for a meeting of six nations.
articles.abstract: After the United States and South Korea began naval exercises as a warning to North Korea, China called for a meeting of six nations.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China moved over the weekend to defuse the latest crisis on the Korean Peninsula, publicly calling on Sunday for “emergency consultations” while beginning what amounted to high-level shuttle diplomacy between North and South Korea.
articles.byline: By Ian Johnson and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: Europe Approves Irish Rescue and New Rules on Bailouts
articles.snippet: Europe’s finance ministers approved an 85 billion euro bailout and agreed on a fund to rescue indebted nations.
articles.abstract: Europe’s finance ministers approved an 85 billion euro bailout and agreed on a fund to rescue indebted nations.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS  Fighting to prevent an accelerating debt crisis from engulfing Portugal and Spain, Europe’s finance ministers approved an 85 billion euro bailout package for Ireland, while also agreeing for the first time to hold private investors accountable for losses in future crises, beginning in 2013.
articles.byline: By Stephen Castle and Liz Alderman

articles.headline: Leaked Cables Offer Raw Look at U.S. Diplomacy
articles.snippet: A trove of State Department cables, obtained by WikiLeaks, offers a look at bargaining by embassies, candid views of foreign leaders and assessments of threats.
articles.abstract: A trove of State Department cables, obtained by WikiLeaks, offers a look at bargaining by embassies, candid views of foreign leaders and assessments of threats.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A cache of a quarter-million confidential American diplomatic cables, most of them from the past three years, provides an unprecedented look at back-room bargaining by embassies around the world, brutally candid views of foreign leaders and frank assessments of nuclear and terrorist threats.
articles.byline: By Scott Shane and Andrew W. Lehren

articles.headline: Around the World, Distress Over Iran
articles.snippet: Cables show how two presidents have dealt with Iran and how President Obama built support for harsher sanctions.
articles.abstract: Cables show how two presidents have dealt with Iran and how President Obama built support for harsher sanctions.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger, James Glanz and Jo Becker

articles.headline: U.S. Expands Role of Diplomats in Spying
articles.snippet: State Department personnel were told to gather the credit card and frequent-flier numbers, schedules and other personal data of foreign officials.
articles.abstract: State Department personnel were told to gather the credit card and frequent-flier numbers, schedules and other personal data of foreign officials.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The United States has expanded the role of American diplomats in collecting intelligence overseas and at the United Nations, ordering State Department personnel to gather the credit card and frequent-flier numbers, work schedules and other personal information of foreign dignitaries.

articles.headline: Robust Sales for Holiday Weekend
articles.snippet: The average amount spent per person from Thursday to Sunday was more than a 6 percent increase over last year.
articles.abstract: The average amount spent per person from Thursday to Sunday was more than a 6 percent increase over last year.
articles.lead_paragraph: More Americans went shopping over the Thanksgiving weekend than in recent memory, and online shopping accounted for the highest percentage of the weekend’s sales yet.

articles.headline: A Media False Alarm Over the T.S.A.
articles.snippet: An outcry about airport security became a story about a story, the noisy sound of a news system feeding on itself.
articles.abstract: An outcry about airport security became a story about a story, the noisy sound of a news system feeding on itself.
articles.lead_paragraph: If a squadron of mad scientists surrounded by supercomputers gathered in a laboratory to try to conjure a single news topic that would blow up large, they could not touch the T.S.A. pat-down story.

articles.headline: Gates Seeking to Contain Military Health Costs
articles.snippet: Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates may ask to raise fees — unchanged since 1995 — for military health care.
articles.abstract: Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates may ask to raise fees — unchanged since 1995 — for military health care.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Francis Brady enjoys a six-figure salary and generous benefits at the consulting firm Booz Allen Hamilton, but as a retired Marine lieutenant colonel he and his family remain on the military’s bountiful lifetime health insurance, Tricare, with fees of only $460 a year. He calls the benefit “phenomenal.”
articles.byline: By Elisabeth Bumiller and Thom Shanker

articles.headline: For PayPal, the Future Is Mobile
articles.snippet: A strategy to expand PayPal, the online payment service, to retailers outside of eBay’s auction business is paying off handsomely.
articles.abstract: A strategy to expand PayPal, the online payment service, to retailers outside of eBay’s auction business is paying off handsomely.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN JOSE, Calif.  When Scott Thompson, the president of PayPal, chats with executives at its parent, eBay, he is diplomatic about the size of his business compared with eBay’s marketplace.

articles.headline: Google Grows, and Works to Retain Nimble Minds
articles.snippet: The pace at a big company is far slower than at a start-up, a difference that matters to the entrepreneurial spirit.
articles.abstract: The pace at a big company is far slower than at a start-up, a difference that matters to the entrepreneurial spirit.
articles.lead_paragraph: When a product manager at Google told his bosses this year that he was quitting to take a job at Facebook, they offered him a large raise. When he said it was not about the money, they told him he could have a promotion, work in a different area or even start his own company inside Google.

articles.headline: In Magazine World, a New Crop of Chiefs
articles.snippet: With new leaders at the four largest magazine companies in the country, 2011 will be a year to watch.
articles.abstract: With new leaders at the four largest magazine companies in the country, 2011 will be a year to watch.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the magazine business, 2011 will be a year to watch — and not just because it could hold answers to lingering questions about the financial health of the industry.

articles.headline: Marketers Discover Trucks Can Deliver More Than Food
articles.snippet: That strategy — pairing a brand’s message with a food truck — has been increasingly employed in recent months, with major advertisers using trucks as rolling sandwich boards.
articles.abstract: That strategy — pairing a brand’s message with a food truck — has been increasingly employed in recent months, with major advertisers using trucks as rolling sandwich boards.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the Heavenly Mountain Resort in Lake Tahoe, Nev., wanted to promote its ski passes this season, it bypassed the usual advertising media like billboards, radio and print ads and instead chose a truck filled with snow cones driven by two improv actors to publicize its message.

articles.headline: Bombings Hit Atomic Experts in Iran Streets
articles.snippet: Two scientists were attacked and one died, prompting accusations that the United States and Israel were trying to disrupt Iran’s nuclear program.
articles.abstract: Two scientists were attacked and one died, prompting accusations that the United States and Israel were trying to disrupt Iran’s nuclear program.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEHRAN  Unidentified assailants riding motorcycles carried out separate bomb attacks here on Monday against two of the country’s top nuclear scientists, killing one and prompting accusations that the United States and Israel were again trying to disrupt Iran’s nuclear program.
articles.byline: By William Yong and Robert F. Worth

articles.headline: Amid Deficit Fears, Obama Freezes Pay
articles.snippet: President Obama’s plan to freeze the pay of federal workers comes before a meeting Tuesday with Congressional leaders.
articles.abstract: President Obama’s plan to freeze the pay of federal workers comes before a meeting Tuesday with Congressional leaders.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Monday announced a two-year pay freeze for civilian federal workers as he sought to address concerns over high annual deficits and appealed to Republicans to find a common approach to restoring the nation’s economic and fiscal health.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Jackie Calmes
